title: Man points out glaring error with Waitrose 'British' lamb hotpot - Mirror Online
text:
Man points out glaring error with Waitrose 'British' lamb hotpot "This product is legal but just downright silly!" Share So tender (Photo: Joff Lee) Share Get daily updates directly to your inbox + Subscribe Could not subscribe, try again later Invalid Email 
There's a consorted effort right now to encourage British consumers to buy British food. 
But British consumers aren't always able to do so, even if they want to – because they can only buy what supermarkets sell (unless they go to independents, of course). 
Farmers for years have been urging the likes of Tesco, Sainsbury's, and Waitrose to make better use of the produce grown and made here in Britain. 
And while there have been some apparent efforts to source from British farmers, a lot of the time, meat is flown in from far away. Here is some very exciting lamb (Photo: Getty Images) Read More Tesco refuses to serve man buying £200 worth of food for homeless 
Lamb is one of the more contentious issues when it comes to British food. Why, when we have such tender and succulent lamb here in the UK – particularly in Wales – do we fly it in from New Zealand? 
David Hughes spotted a lamb hotpot in Waitrose recently. On the packet, Waitrose proudly calls its dish 'British'. And they're right in a way – hotpot is one of our country's most hearty meals. But...the lamb is from New Zealand. It's a bit silly. Read More Woman finds the most Waitrose shopping list ever – with incredibly specific instructions 
"Not often that Waitrose has a bad hair day," David said. "This product is legal but just downright silly!" 
Obviously, supermarkets have reasons for flying in lamb. It's to do with the seasons. Lambs grow up, as you're probably aware. But shoppers want lamb year-round. 
Still, this is a bit of an error by Waitrose. 
Waitrose told Mirror Online : "To ensure the provenance of the lamb in the meals is clearer (it has always been on back of pack) we have stickered all packs on the front. 
"We are about to re-launch the range with the branding ‘Classic’, removing the large ‘British’ reference from the front of pack. 
"This was only ever supposed to denote the origin of the recipe but we understand why confusion has arisen. In addition, we have challenged our supplier to explore the practicalities of using more British lamb in our ready meals. 
"At the moment, because of our policy of only buying from our dedicated supply chain and using the whole carcass, we do not have sufficient raw material available to make this change but, nevertheless, we are exploring this option." Like us on Facebook
